body.value: Ultra has insulas nulla est amplius hominibus nota habitacio neque facilis nautarum transitus, quoniam arcentur ab aere navigantes.
Beyond these islands, there is no other home known to men and not even the passage of sailors is easy, since they are repelled by the air.
In hoc mari australis poli aspectus navigant septentrionali absconso.
In the South Polar Sea, they navigate with the North Pole not in sight.
Hic porcus dictus marinus sicut terrestris in luto rostro proprio colligit escas
This animal, called the sea hog, gathers its food with its snout like the land hog.
King Cambellannas [Tamerlane?], son of the great Khan.
Hic uxores virorum suorum exequias ignotas vive comitantur et si que pavide renuunt ad id compellentur
Here the wives living mount the funeral pyre of their husbands, but if any refuse through fear, they are forced to this.
Huis lacus sunt auque ad potum a menissime et suaves
The waters of this lake are very pleasant and sweet for drinking.
Hostia Gangis fluvii curus latitudo est XV miliaribus in cuius ripa arundines adeo magne ut armum excedant insule et nuces quas Indas dicimus procreant
The mouth of the Ganges River, the width of which is fifteen miles, on whose banks grow canes so large that they exceed [the size of] the arm, and the islands grow nuts which we call Indian.
Istorum mos est ut senio confecti sese in mari per montes abruptos perimant.
It is the custom of these people, as old age comes on, to cast themselves from the steep precipices into the sea.
Hic adeo ... habitant ex Ebreorum tribus decem generacione com dimidia Benjamin, qui legis sue effreni degeneres vitam qui ducunt epicuriam.
Here dwell the ten lost tribes of the Hebrew race with the half-tribe of Benjamin, who, unrestrained by their law and being degenerates, pass an epicurean existence.
Has turres construxit presbyter Johannes rex ne inclusis hominibus ad eum pateat accessus.
King Prester John built these towers in order that those shut therein might not have access to him.
De hac gente, hoc est ex tribu Dan nasceturis est antichristus qui magica arte montes istos apperiens ad chrisocolas subvertendos accedet.
From this race, that is, from the tribe of Dan, Antichrist is to be born, who, opening these mountains by magic art, will come to overthrow the worshipers of Christ.

Insularum notarum Traprobana maior que sexdecies contenis milibus passuum patere ambitu affirmatur. Post hanc Anglia inde Java maior, inde minor, post eas Ibernia et Xilana, post quam Cecilia, post hanc Sardinia, inde Corsica, inde Cyprius et Candia. Huius Traprobane que eorum lingua Cimiteria dictur incole crudeles aures magnos, in auribus ornatas habent linteis vestiti, ydolatre omnes, piere, camphora et auro plurimo reduntantes, piperis arbor edere similis grana ut iuniperi ferens. Huius insule partem anthropophagi habitant continue cum vicinis bellantes capita humana pro thesauro recondunt esis carnibus et qui plura capita habuerit ditior est

Of the islands which are known, Taprobana is said to have a circumference of more than sixteen hundred miles, next to which is Anglia, then Java the Greater and Java the Less: after these islands Ceylon, then Sicily, and after this Sardinia, and following in order, Corsica, Cyprus and Candia [Crete]. The inhabitants of this Taprobana, which in their language is called Ciamutera [Sumatra], are barbarians, having large ears in which they wear ornaments, and they dress in linen clothes. They are all idolaters. They have an abundance of pepper, camphor, and much gold. The pepper tree when it bears has seeds like the juniper. Cannibals inhabit a part of this island, who, continually waging war with their neighbors, make a collection of human heads as treasures, and he who has the most heads is the richest.
Hec figura piscis nuper in Candia vacas circa litus maris pascentes de mari exiliens, invasit qui captus Veneciis delatus est cuiusque effigies configurata ad loca multa terre est transmissa.

This species of fish, recently [caught?] in Candia, feeds upon the meadows of the shore like cows. It was captured and exhibited to the Venetians. It was mounted and carried about to many parts of the country.
Hic copiose reperitur aurum cum jocalibus et lapidibus preciosis.
Here gold is found in abundance with jewels and precious stones.

Sanday et Bandan dicuntur insule iste, nam Sanday crocea, nuces muscatas et macis, Bandan vero gariofilorum copiam ad Javas transmittunt utrisque incole nigri sunt. Bandan item triplicis generis habet psitacos, rubeos, croceosque rostro versicolores et albos. Albi namque galinis sunt pares qui transeuntibus locuntur et dant responsa.

These islands are called Sanday and Bandan. Sanday sends safron, nuts, muscatas, and maces to the Javas, Bandan an abundance of cloves. The inhabitants of both are black. Bandan, moreover, has parrots of three kinds: red ones, those of variegated color with yellow beaks, and white ones the size of hens.
Derbent quod lingua euorum id quod porte ferri.
This is Derbent, which in their language [means] a gate of iron.
Huic regioni que catayum vel eorum lingua cambalec dicitur dominatur magnus canis.
The Great Khan rules this region, which is called Cathay, or, in their language, Cambalec.
In these mountains, carbuncles are found.
Maragatna ubi aloes, aurum, argentum et gemmarum habundant genera.
Maragatna where aloe, gold, silver, and all sorts of gems are abundant.
Rex Cambalech hoc est magnus cannis.
King (of) Cambalech, that is, the Great Khan.
Isti simt ex Gog generacione qui cubitus altitudinem non excedunt anni aetatis nonum non actingunt et continue a grubius infestantur.
These are of the generation of Grog, who do not exceed the height of a cubit, who do not attain the age of nine years, and who are continually molested by cranes.
Hec provincia Macina dicta elephantos gignit, hugus incole serpentibus vescuntur deliciose affatin et facies suas veriis punctis et coloribus stiloque ferreo depingunt et sola uxore sunt contenti.

This province of Macina produces elephants. Its inhabitants subsist on serpents, regarding them as great delicacies. They tattoo their faces with various punctures and colors and with an iron stylus. They are contented with one wife.
Mains Gauge qui aliter daua dicitur.
Spring of Ganges which is also called the Dava.

Xilana insula trium milium miliariorum ambitum continens, rubinis, saphiris, granatis et occulis gate decora, cinamomum ex arboribus salicibus nostris similibus gignit. In insula hac lacus est in cuius medio civitas nobilis cuius incole astrologie dediti omnia futura predicunt

The island of Ceylon, having a circumference of three thousand miles, is rich in rubies, sapphires, and cat's-eyes, and produces cinnamon from trees similar to our willow tree. On this island, there is a lake, in the middle of which is a noble city whose inhabitants, given over to astrology, predict all future events.

In hac regione depinxerunt quidam paradisum deliciarum, alii vero ultra Indias ad orientem eum esse dixerunt. Sed quoniam hec est cosmographorum descripcio, qui nullam de eo fecerunt mentionem, ideo omittitur hic de eo narratio

In this region, certain ones have depicted the paradise of delights. Others, indeed, have said that it is beyond the Indies to the east. But since that is a representation of cosmographers who have given no description of it, therefore an account of it is here omitted.

Plinius 144 piscium genera enumerat, inter quos hunc serram nole describit asserens eum cum eius eumque crista serrata sepuis naves indorum frangere solo impetu, ac ubi serram infra ligna affixerit ab eis retentus evadere non valet se ipsum perimit.

Pliny enumerates 144 species of fishes, and among them he describes this swordfish, asserting that, with its swordlike beak, it often transfixes the shops of the natives of India by single attack; but when this fish becomes fast within [the ship's side]
Sinus persicus in quo mare fluit et refluit velut occeanus
The Persian Gulf, in which the sea ebbs and flows as in the ocean.
Hic fons est a media die ad mediam noctem buliens, alia diei et noctis parte regit. Et hy montes continue ardentes.

Ultra hanc equinoctialem [tradit] Ptolomeus terram incognitam, sed Pomponius […] dubium an sit possibilis nautarum transitus ab hoc loco […] Indorum […] mult[…] per has partes ab India ad Ispanias […] pertransisse, precipue Pomponius capitolo ultimo

Beyond this equinoctial line Ptolemy records an unknown land, but Pomponius, and in addition many others, raising a doubt whether a voyage is possible from this place to India, [the Indians] say that many have passed through these parts from India to the Spains, and [...] especially Pomponius in his last chapter.

Hoc mare dicitur Oceanus, qui a cosmographis infinitus descriptus. Undique terram preter eius partem fer[…] hic configuratam cooperit. Qui […] a vi lunari commotus, diebus singulis lunaribus circa terram fluit et refluit, ut ait Albertus in Naturalibus.

This sea is called the ocean which, according to cosmographers, stretches out infinitely in every direction, covering the earth except about a fourth part here laid down. This sea, disturbed by the force of the moon, ebbs and flows around the earth every lunar day, as Albertus says in his Natural History.
Isti sunt montes lune qui lingue egiptiaca dicuntur gebelcan a quibus nilus fluvius oritus atque estatis tempore dissolutis in apso nivibus maior affluit

There are the Mountains of the Moon, which, in the Egyptian language, are called Gebelcan, in which mountains the river Nile rises, and from which, in the summertime, when the snows melt, a very large stream forms.
In hac lacu insula est tenis que lucos silvasque ac grande appollinis templum sustinet natat et quocumque venti agunt appellitur
In this lake there is an island, Tana by name, which contains forests and groves and a great temple of Appolo. This island floats and is driven in whatever direction the winds blow.
Isti belaurum castelatorum acie ordinata preliantur.
These people fight in a battle line of castled beasts.
Isti sunt qui vitus honorant degeneres. Inter eos nullum nomen est proprium et orientem occidentemve Solem dira imprecatione tuentur.
These are the people who live degenerate lives, among whom there is no distinguishing name, who behold the rising and the setting sun with direful imprecations.
Preter ptolemei tradicionem est hic gaffus sed pomponius eum[...]
Contrary to the tradition of Ptolemy, this is a gulf, but Pomponius speaks of it with its islands.
Hec est vera cosmographorum cum marino accordata tradicio, quarundam frivolis narrationibus rejectis 1457
This is the true tradition of cosmographers in accord with Marinus [marine charts?], their unreliable records being excluded, 1457.
Hic jacet corpus sancti Thome aph[ostoli]
Here lies the body of the apostle Saint Thomas.

Indicus pelagus multis occupatur insulis, scopulis et scirtis, hec ideo eorum naves pluribus construuntur medianis quatenus si in aliqua parte fragantur pars reliqua ad eorum iter complendum sufficienter suppleat. Quas etiam pluribus malis de tribus ad X communientes velis quoque ex arundinibus et plmarum foliis contextis utentes velocissime suum curcum perficiunt. Et eis permaxime speciebus et ceteris aromatibus oneratis sepius ad Mechan Arabie applicantes mercatoribus occidentalibus per mutantionem mercium iniunt

The Indian Sea is filled with many islands, rocks, and sand banks. Their ships, therefore, are constructed with many compartments, to the end that if they are broken in any part, the remaining parts may be sufficiently strong to complete the course. These, moreover, are supplied with several masts, from three to ten, and having sails made of reeds and palm leaves joined together, they pursue their courses with great rapidity. And these [ships], loaded in particular with spices and other aromatics, sailing rather often to Mecca in Arabia, trade with the Western merchants through and exchange of their goods.
Caila, ubi pro papiro foliis arborum utuntur
Caila, where tree leaves are used instead of papyrus.

Hec insule Jaue dicte sunt quarum major tribus alters duobus milibus miliarum protendunter absuntque a continente mensis navigatione et immundi habitant homines quibus hominem occidere pro ludo; uxores quotlibet sumunt.

These islands are called Java, of which the greater in circumference is three, and the other two thousand miles. They are one month's journey from the continent and are one hundred miles apart. Ignorant and wicked men inhabit these islands, who think it sport to kill a man. They have as many wives as they wish.
Porte ferri ubi Alexander Tartaros inclusit.
Iron gate where Alexander imprisoned the Tartars.

De Ybernia duo narrantur unum quod in ea est abissus dictus putens sancti patritij per quem ad partes inferoram descendit[ur?] multaque miranda in eo vident sepius et narant incole. Aliud est quod eorum arbores quedam fructus ferant qui intra marcescendo vermen generant qui inde crescendo pilosus vel plumatus tandem alatus effectus tanguam avis evolat

Concerning Ireland two [stories] are told. One of these [asserts] that there is an abyss called the well of St. Patrick through which one descends into the lower regions. In this [well] the inhabitants often see many wonderful things and tell about them. The other [story relates] that certain of their trees bear fruit which, decaying within, produces a worm which, as it subsequently develops, becomes hairy and feathered, and, provided with wings, flies like a bird.
"Testango which Pizigani calls Testango is Tyshkandy on Mertwyi-Kultuk Bay

The ancient capital of Khwarazm on the Darjalyk. Organzin is erroneously placed on the Caspian Sea. Destroyed first by Genghis Khan in 1221, and again by Timur, this great Asiatic frontier commercial city in the time of Conti was in ruins. The new city, Urgench, lies far to the east of the ancient city.
